abstract: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
snippet: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
lead_paragraph: The results of the bank stress tests have been trickling out for days, from Washington and from Wall Street, and the leaks seem to confirm what many bankers feel in their bones: despite all those bailouts, some of the nation’s largest banks still need more money.

headline.main: Banks Need Funds, but Taxpayers May Not Have to Pay
headline.print_headline: Some Big Banks Are Seen in Need Of More Capital

byline.original: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

abstract: Bank of America‘s chief, Kenneth D. Lewis, and top federal officials will be asked by a Congressional panel to testify next month about claims that the bank was pressured by the government to complete its purchase of Merrill Lynch, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the investigation.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America‘s chief, Kenneth D. Lewis, and top federal officials will be asked by a Congressional panel to testify next month about claims that the bank was pressured by the government to complete its purchase of Merrill Lynch, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the investigation.

headline.main: House Panel to Ask Bank of America Chief to Testify, Report Says

abstract: Update | 6:28 p.m. Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America disclosed on Thursday afternoon their plans to raise new capital, amid the release of the results of the government-conducted stress tests of banks.
lead_paragraph: Update | 6:28 p.m. Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America disclosed on Thursday afternoon their plans to raise new capital, amid the release of the results of the government-conducted stress tests of banks.

headline.main: Banks Begin Push to Raise More Capital
